bestBHT.bht: Jesus speaks of abstaining from earthly wine until the day he partakes of it anew in the kingdom of God. This statement carries a symbolic meaning, signifying the joys of heaven. It points to a time when earthly distinctions will cease and God will be all in all. The mention of wine represents the heavenly state of eternal bliss, emphasizing the everlasting reign of God.

John Gill: I will drink no more of the fruit of the vine; that is, wine, until that day that I drink it new; in a figurative and mystical sense; by which are meant the joys of heaven."
By which are meant the joys of heaven.

When the kingdom of the Mediator will be delivered up, and there will be no distinction of government; but God, Father, Son, and Spirit, will be all in all, and shall reign in the saints, and they with them, to all eternity.
John Wesley: I will drink no more of the fruit of the vine, till I drink it new in the kingdom of God."
I shall drink no more before I die: the next wine I drink will not be earthly, but heavenly.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 14:25, Jesus says, I will drink no more of the fruit of the vine until that day that I drink it new. This statement holds a figurative and mystical meaning, referring to the joys of heaven. Jesus is speaking of the future kingdom of God, where distinctions of earthly government will cease and God will be all in all. The wine he refers to is not earthly, but heavenly, representing the eternal reign of God in the saints.

In this particular passage, Jesus declares that he will not partake in the earthly wine again until he drinks it anew in the kingdom of God. This statement carries a deep and symbolic meaning, referring to the ultimate joy and bliss found in heaven. It signifies the time when all earthly distinctions will cease, and God will reign over everything. The wine mentioned here represents the heavenly and eternal state, emphasizing the divinity and everlasting sovereignty of God.

Jesus states that he will refrain from partaking in the earthly wine until the day he drinks it anew in the kingdom of God. His words contain figurative and mystical significance, pointing towards the eternal joys found in heaven. This indicates a time when earthly distinctions will no longer exist, and God will reign over all things. The mention of wine symbolizes the heavenly and everlasting reign of God, emphasizing his divine authority.

Jesus makes a significant statement in Mark 14:25, expressing that he will not drink of the earthly wine until he drinks it anew in the kingdom of God. This declaration holds figurative and mystical implications, referring to the joys of heaven that await believers. It signifies a future time when all earthly governance will be relinquished, and God will reign supreme. The mention of wine in this context serves as a representation of the heavenly and eternal realities, emphasizing the everlasting sovereignty and glory of God.

Jesus speaks of abstaining from earthly wine until the day he partakes of it anew in the kingdom of God. This statement carries a symbolic meaning, signifying the joys of heaven. It points to a time when earthly distinctions will cease and God will be all in all. The mention of wine represents the heavenly state of eternal bliss, emphasizing the everlasting reign of God.
